Building the PCB

The PCB is the substrate on which the switches are connected. It hosts the microcontroller, the LEDs and any other features you with to add. It also provides a mechanical connection between the switches, and can make a board more stiff. You will have control over every aspect of this circuit borad, and you can tailor it to your liking and needs.

Getting Started:

Download kicad

Kicad is a software that we will use to design the schematic, route the PCB, and place all of the components that we need to use.

Once you have Kicad downloaded, open it and create a new project. Save it to a folder that you have easy access to.

In a new web browser tab, open GitHub

Sign in / Create an account. Click the green button that says Create a new repository.

Name your repository. I'm going to use `Keyboard-return`. Give the repository a description. For my project, I'm going to use `A mechanical keyboard with detachable numpad, OLED displays, rotary encoders, and QMK firmware. ` but yours should be different. It should be a description of the features of your keyboard as well as any special processes you used to design it.

Select 'Add a Readme file'. This will serve as the front page of your repository.

For the gitignore template, select Kicad. This will help prevent sensitive information from making its way onto the public internet.

Pick a license. Use choosealisence.com. I will use the CERN Open Hardware Licence Version 2 because it doesn't let people make closed source or proprietary versions.

Click create repository.

Now we need to install the GitHub Command Line Interface (cli): GitHub CLI

On MacOS, if you have brew installed, use brew install gh

Now run gh auth login So your github account gets credited for any contributions you make to your repository.

Navigate to the folder that your Kicad project is saved in: cd Path/To/Your/Folder

Now, run git init To initialize the folder as a git repository

Connect Your Local Folder to the GitHub Repository: git remote add origin https://github.com/your-username/your-repo-name.git

Now, every time you make a significant change you want to be added to the verisoning system, just run:

git add .


git commit -m "Initial commit"

And then, push your changes to the remote repository:

git push -u origin master

Creating the Schematic

Open KiCad. Create a new project in your git folder. Name it with the name of your project.

Open the schematic file for the project, by clicking on the Schematic Editor.

Welcome to the schematic editor, where we will build all of the circuits and connections for the PCB.

here is a list of keyboard shortcuts that work in this software:

Choosing a microcontroller:

The first step of this project will be chosing a microcontroller that can accomodate all of the features your project needs.

The first and most obvious consideration is connectivity - Do you want your keyboard to have bluetooth connectivity? If so, should it also have USB connectivity?

It is preferable to find a board with all of those features built in, so you don't have to do crazy workarounds to make those things work.

Look at Adafruit's Guide on chosing a microcontroller.

Another consideration should be compatibility with firmwares. Visit QMK Docs for compatibility details.

For my keyboard, I want bluetooth support, lots of pins, and ideally QMK support.

One of my favorite new microcontrollers, the ESP32-S3, has most of these features, with the notable exception being QMK Support. I am comfortable enough with firmware, but that should be a large deterrent to someone less advanced.

I'm going to use it anyways, because of the ease of hardware development.

I'm going to start with a stepping stone: The Adafruit Feather ESP32 S3.

This board's design files are already open source under the CC BY-SA 3.0, so we can use and modify them in our project. All we have to do is credit the authors, Adafruit, in our own open-source project. We can even use the derivative commerically.

All we have to do for this head start is find the repository hosting the board designs here.

Download the schematic file (The file with extension .sch.)

Import it into Kicad with File>Import>Non-Kicad Schematic

This process is exactly the same with other microcontrollers. You can start from scratch, or build upon an already existing board.

Now, look at the different components of the schematic. It's split into various sections.

There are separate elements for the usb connector, the pins, and the microcontroller itself.

Importing Libraries

Before we add all of the circuitry for our keyboard, we must add some libraries filled with all of the different components we're going to use.

I like to use AI03's brilliant MXV2 libraries. To use these, there are no special symbols that need to be imported. This library uses default built-in symbols, which is incredibly convenient.

Open the link to the github and click code>Download .zip

Continue this later

Now, we have to decide on a layout. Here Is a great guide on drop.com for different layouts.

Use Keyboard-Layout-Editor to make it real. Save that design for later.

Once you have your design, divide the keys into rows and columns to connect to the microcontroller. Our keyboard will use a key matrix, in which current is passed through each of the rows, and current is read at each of the columns. The microcontroller puts voltage into one of the rows and reads all of the columns, and if one of the columns is active, the key at that index was pressed. This is repeeated for every row, hundreds or thousands of times per second.

Note the number of rows and columns, and come back to the schematic.

Add a symbol for SW_Push by pressing the A key and searching for it.
